dt: {bc}a geometrical figure or element (such as a cube or sphere) having three dimensions {dx}see {dxt|Volume Formulas Table|volume|table}{/dx}

{bc}a substance that does not flow perceptibly under moderate stress, has a definite capacity for resisting forces (such as compression or tension) which tend to deform it, and under ordinary conditions retains a definite size and shape
{bc}the part of a solution or suspension that when freed from solvent or suspending medium has the qualities of a solid
{bc}a compound word whose members are joined together without a hyphen

dt.t: Ted Evans might be one of those people. … "Can you do me a {wi}solid{/wi} and watch my stuff?" he'll ask, returning the favor if anyone else needs to do the same.
So her husband did her a {wi}solid{/wi} and dropped her off for the afternoon, where she was free to sketch some of the exhibits …

shortdef: a geometrical figure or element (such as a cube or sphere) having three dimensions

a substance that does not flow perceptibly under moderate stress, has a definite capacity for resisting forces (such as compression or tension) which tend to deform it, and under ordinary conditions retains a definite size and shape
the part of a solution or suspension that when freed from solvent or suspending medium has the qualities of a solid —usually used in plural

dt: {bc}any of the five possible regular polyhedrons that include the regular forms of the tetrahedron, hexahedron, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron

shortdef: any of the five possible regular polyhedrons that include the regular forms of the tetrahedron, hexahedron, octahedron, dodecahedron, and icosahedron

dt: {bc}a mathematical solid conceived as formed by the revolution of a plane figure about an axis in its plane

shortdef: a mathematical solid conceived as formed by the revolution of a plane figure about an axis in its plane
